For anyone thinking "why is this important" here is a honest real world example.

Even for manageable datasets, even a passing understanding of the concepts and a little research can help take things like processing a large volume of data from a 6 hour process, down to 2 hours (that's what contractors are for). We brought in a few math PhDs to look at some data processing that was literally taking 6 hours on a good day (12 if it was month end) and after a few weeks found some tweaks that took it down to 2 hours. How? They applied set and group theory to the data to streamline the processing. At $50,000 an hour for total processing costs (that includes lost productivity costs while waiting for results) that means we saved, daily, $200,000 in costs or roughly 50 million dollars a year.

You can in life brute force a lot of data, but a good mathematician can work with your DBAs and programmers and find much better solutions to problems. Imagine if you negotiated a pay bonus equal to 1% of the savings you can provide?

Ironically, I find the abstract definition of a group to be far more concrete than trying to generalize from "symmetries". Also, I think of it from the view of Haskell and type theory. A type (set) `G` is a group if you can write `(<>) : G -> G -> G`, `id : G`, and `inv : G -> G`, such that:
`a <> (b <> c) ≡ (a <> b) <> c` (`(<>)` is associative),
`a <> id ≡ id <> a ≡ a` (`id` is the left- and right-identity of `(<>)`), and
`a <> inv a ≡ inv a <> a ≡ id` (`inv` yields the inverse element of the given element).

So your point around 10:30 about the formalities being a hassle, while likely true for most people, definitely isn't always the case. These one-off examples of flipped snowflakes -- to me -- just add confusion at best and infuriating annoyance at worst.

And as a side note: making a multiplication table about groups, such that r²s * r = rs, was… probably a bold move considering you just kinda let that slip by without explaining it when first shown. Noting the importance of having exactly one instance of 1 per row and column may have been a good idea too, but trying to avoid the specifics of invertibility and such, I can see why you didn't.

At 3:10 I think it is important to note that the loosest sense of structure is not really "no structure". Any symmetry should preserve the "sameness" structure, i.e. if x and y are same (distinct), their images should be same (distinct). This is what motivates the inverse element axiom. For instance, we could map a line to itself, so that the map is onto but not one-to-one. And although we get the same line, this map would not be considered a symmetry.

So symmetry exists at ridiculously large numbers. And in other fields of math and science those ridiculously large numbers appear to complete equations. Which gives even more validity to its existence. Everyone is wondering what purpose does such symmetry serve in the grand scale of the universe. My simple response to that is that the universe continues to expand and at a very fast rate, which means everything within the universe is being pulled into infinity creating even more numbers and therefore demanding larger cosmic bodies/shapes. They stopped at the monster group not because it ended there but because we, just stopped counting.

This video is beyond beautiful. It starts with something that is quintessential, that we all have an intuition about and can feel but is hard to put into words, i.e. symmetry. "Symmetry is everywhere" is an understatement. It literally is in every group. Cayley's theorem: "Every group G is isomorphic to a subgroup of a symmetric group".

What that means for us (well, kind of) is that every form of beauty that has pleased our eye, anything and everything that we find symmetric has a mathematical representation. This is very powerful. Because of groups, we can abstract out the actions and objects across domains and study them. And because of that theorem, we can abstract out the very concept of a group by just dealing with symmetric groups. That cute little fact allows the entire subject of group theory to be introduced, talked about, and be awed at by just studying the symmetry of snowflakes (among other things).

This realization after the fact is enlightening, but to have thought of it, and create a video this beautiful is sheer genius. This conveys a very important point: The most influential pedagogies can only be devised by those that have an intimate understanding of the subject matter. We love you, Grant!

First impressions: Primes are not the building blocks of whole integers. They are their building blocks *through factorisation*. You made the choice to consider factorisation more important. So primes become important.

Symmetry is not the building method of the universe. The universe builds itself gradually, it has no need to be symmetrical. It needs *Balance*. But balance implies, that the balance can break. To build new forms of balance.

Assuming symmetry as the starting point, and trying to classify the symmetry should then result in artifacts that do not wish to bend to it. The outlying groups you mention are likely an indication that viewing the world, and numbers, as built on symmetry, is wrong.

More importantly, it's an indication our math is no perfect system. Merely a tool to help describe what we see. Additionally, 196,000 dimensions is just too abstract to figure out. I recall first seeing this video when it came out and feeling like it didn't completely capture the sense of what a group was - based on my then- understanding of what a group was.
Now, I feel like this video is perfect as an introduction to group theory.

Groups might just be the most fundamental thing math has to offer. Truth, sets of axioms and theories can be seen as rings (and if truth isn't fundamental in math, I don't know what is), and for any structure, Aut(S) tells us how complicated the structure is and how much you can squeeze it and turn it around itself while keeping its fundamental properties - and by extension, we learn how much.
In some way, groups measure how "specific" the instance you're studying is for how much structure you decide to put on it, which has a very deep meaning in category and model theory.


The fact that groups were studied first in the setting of Galois theory, ie field theory, a theory that model theory works very well on, is kind of amusing as well. I'd even let myself go as far as thinking that it had to be this way, no one was going to look at a topological space, get a feeling for the absolute mess that is its fundamental group (even C minus two points has a disgusting one) and go "yeah let's study that thing".

If anyone wonders,
for the case of a preserved orthogonal cube transformation with a possibility of mirror (flip), only the following fundamentals are needed:
4 90-degree rotations over X axis (RX)
4 90-degree rotations over Y axis (RY)
2 90-degree rotations over Z axis (RZ)
2 mirror states over X axis (MX)

This leads to 48 unique "forms" (as shown in this video), but can be encoded in just 6 bits
RX -> 2 bits (to encode 0, 1, 2, 3)
RY -> 2 bits (to encode 0, 1, 2, 3)
RZ -> 1 bit (rotated or not)
MX -> 1 bit (mirrored or not)

(I call them "forms" -- I'm not a mathematician and I don't care)

The following vertex maps are used as constrained permutations (actions)
ID = 0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7 (the identity of a cube)
RX = 1,5,6,2,0,4,7,3
RY = 1,2,3,0,5,6,7,4
RZ = 4,5,1,0,7,6,2,3
MX = 3,2,1,0,7,6,5,4

The full encoding space is 2^6 = 64, however there are 16 ambiguous states, all of which are listed here
1. RY * RZ = 3RX * RY
2. RX * RY * RZ = RY (try it! rotate a cube once per each axis and see where it leads you; I'm using left-handedness btw)
3. 2RX * RY * RZ = RX * RY
4. 3RX * RY * RZ = 2RX * RY
5. 3RY * RZ = RX * 3RY
6. RX * 3RY * RZ = 2RX * 3RY
7. 2RX * 3RY * RZ = 3RX * 3RY
8. 3RX * 3RY * RZ = 3RY
9. RY * RZ * MX = 3RX * RY * MX
10. RX * RY * RZ * MX = RY * MX
11. 2RX * RY * RZ * MX = RX * RY * MX
12. 3RX * RY * RZ * MX = 2RX * RY * MX
13. 3RY * RZ * MX = RX * 3RY * MX
14. RX * 3RY * RZ * MX = 2RX * 3RY * MX
15. 2RX * 3RY * RZ * MX = 3RX * 3RY3 * MX
16. 3RX * 3RY * RZ * MX = 3RY * MX

This leaves us with 46 - 16 = 48 unique forms.

In case you now wonder WHY, I'm a game dev and this makes storing orthogonal transformation very light and from these states I can snappily produce the actual transformation matrix (or a quaternion) on demand. Think Minecraft but with voxels that can be oriented every which way.

I was also VERY interested to see whether such encoding would require storing all logical transformations (3 rotations, 3 mirrors), or just a subset of them (as it turned out, the full 3D reality can be "compressed" into a 2.5D rotation with a single mirror). I had my intuitions regarding mirrors, but couldn't really figure the rotations out without proper research.

Lots of detailed explanation for claims which seem obviously and facially false. Viz., at 11 mins the claim that a permutation of 4 items is dual to the rotations of a cube. Since this is clearly untrue, the narrator loses a sensible viewer at this point.
Of course, the entire subject of group theory proves so incomprehensible and so obviously counterfactual that it quickly grows clear we're dealing with the equivalent of feng shui or chi or orgone energy. Like most advanced mathematics, group theory quickly becomes so riddled with evident gibberish, incapable of being explained to any reasonable person, that it's rapidly self-evident that we're dealing with a scam. Like orgone energy or elixirs of immortality, we're dealing with nonsense cloaked by jargon which can't be made clear. The lack of clarity isn't a bug: it's a feature, necessary to cloak the essential meaningless of the discussion.
This becomes exceptionally clear around the 15 minute mark where the assertion that polynomials beyond degree 5 have no close-form formulaic solution that we're dealing with a con job. The narrator can't explain why this is allegedly true and can't provide any concrete evidence for it. The bafflegab quickly becomes so dense that multilevel marketing pitches and astrology come irresisitably to mind.
Obviously I'm too stupid to understand advanced math, but least I'm bright enough to realize it. People who spew this kind of jargon don't even seem to have that going for them.
The older I get, the clearer it becomes that if a smart person can't explain something to you in simple terms no matter how hard they try, you're dealing with a crude con job. No one has ever been able to explain group theory to me, or eigenvectors, or a tensor. Whenever I ask about details ("Is a tensor a matrix of vectors?" "Oh, no, no, no," "Is a tensor a matrix of derivatives?" "Oh, no, no, not at all," "Is a tensor a continuous operation on a vector field?" "Haha, no, absolutely not," and so on ad infinitum) the response magically changes. No one can explain what group theory or a tensor or an eigenvector actually _is_, only what it is _not_. Which of course means that the object under consideration can never be defined at all.
And if you can't define something at all, but can only spew jargon, in the slippery manner of a snake oil salesperson fum-fuhing and what-aboutism-ing, the only reasonably conclusion is that it's all a frantically failed attempt to distract us from the evident reality that what the person is talking about is fraudulent drivel and has no discernible meaning.

I will be completely honest: I pride myself on being intelligent and being able to comprehend "big complicated ideas", but all I really managed to glean from this video is the existence of two suspiciously-similar numbers in two tangentially-related areas of mathematics. It's not immediately obvious to me how this information is useful for anything whatsoever, not just in the physical world but in the mathematical world as well. I assume that people who understand the topic are furiously investigating the possible existence of underlying concepts that would enable such a suspicious similarity to exist, but it also seems plausible that 196884 being suspiciously-similar to 196883 is a coincidence -- just like it's a coincidence that 5 is suspiciously similar to 4. After all, we live in a universe wherein events happen Never, Once, or Repeatedly, so having 2 nearly-identical (but not completely identical) events occur is more likely to be 2 singular events rather than an unusually short pattern.

4,294,967,296 - the number of values that can be held by a 32-bit integer, and a value that very often shows up in games as the highest something can be before adding 1 more causes an overflow error reduces you down to 0. If you're playing a game and find a way to use an attack such that it deals this much damage, you have probably dealt the highest amount of damage that can possibly be dealt. If you accrue this much in-game money, you likely can't possibly have more. (technically the number you see is 1 lower than this because computers count starting from 0 but whatever you get the idea)
Shoutouts also to 2,147,483,648 - the highest value you'll see for a 32-bit integer that is allowed to hold negative values. in this case if you add 1 more you'll get -2,147,483,647 ... or in some cases, you can get yourself down to -2,147,483,647 and subtract one more to reach 2,147,483,648. This is a common method of actually achieving the maximum possible of something in a game, since it's typically easier to lose, rid yourself of, or reduce something in a game than it is to gain, acquire, or increase it.

In older games, you might instead be capped at 255 (8-bit integer), or 65535(16-bit integer)

8:20 The most important question: There a 4 Pis. Where do they go?

196,883 is cleanly divisible by 47, which is a prime number unless I am mistaken.
196,883/47=4,189
4,189 is itself cleanly divisible by 59. Yet another prime number.
4,189/59=71
Not only is 71 yet another prime number, we see a pattern. 47, 59, 71. There's a clean gap of 12 between each prime number used in the division. But there's a catch, because if we go down 12 and multiply the first number by 35, it's not a prime number. But we drop 12 again, 35 becomes 23 - a prime number. Drop another 12, we get 11 and can't drop any more without going into the negatives. So what if we go up from 71? We get to 83, 95 - not a prime number - 107, 119, 131, 143, 155.
Every fifth number in that +/- 12 sequence is invariably not a prime number, but the other four are.

There's a reason why that sequence exists, but I'm not good enough at math to figure out the pillars that reason is standing on.

I had to take Modern Algebra I and II for my Bachelor's, and I actually had to drop Modern I the first time I took it because the professor tried to use teach about symmetry instead of from the definitions. I spent almost half a semester stumbling and flailing, unable to visualize or wrap my head around it, and unable to memorize the Cayley tables for different groups. When I tried again with a different professor, who taught based around the formal definitions, everything immediately clicked and it became one of my favorite classes I'd ever taken.

One of the things I love about math is that there's usually more than one way to think about or approach a problem. So while I'm glad that other people learned from the symmetry group lens of it, it took me a minute to get over how weird it felt to hear someone say the definitions weren't how they learned it.

One thing I struggle(d) with is the notion that the 'elements' of a group can be what feel like 'operations.' Like a group of reflections/rotations of a snowflake and then having a right-to-left 'multiplication' doesn't seem intuitive when other groups are 'integers' under 'multiplication' (in the way we usually think 'multiplication' ). The latter feels like a group of items and an operation between them. The former seems like different operations to perform on one item. It's like a group where the group is 'add 0,' 'multiply by 1,' 'raise to the first power,' 'subtract 0,' 'divide by 1,' ...  any other identity-multiplication such that a*x = x... and calling all those operations a 'group.' It just always seemed weird to me.

the quadratic formula portion of this video reminds me of a time in math class years ago. i was working on a large problem in a college trigonometry class and struggling with collapsing it down when i started thinking about the programming classes i was also taking at the time. i saw some structures within the two sides of the problem that looked similar so i divided both sides of the equation by the same function, not a single number but i put both sides over the same equation. i rapidly figured out the problem and got the correct answer. then my math teacher told me that i wasn't allowed to do that, but never really told me why. the best theory i could come up with was that what i had done circumvented some of the learning process and would have been impossible to grade fairly.

it is common practice in programming to plug entire functions into other functions to perform a complex task, so i figured why couldn't i do the same thing in trigonometry as long as i was operating on both sides of the equation equally.

So, did I get this right? These groups tell us the number of ways objects can be symmetric within certain, different rules. Some of the rules will define the amount of dimension i.e. there's a group that encompasses 2D objects such as squares or prime polygons and all the ways they can be symmetric etc. Some don't have dimensions as the rules define the objects in relation to another like orders and such. Some groups are stricter than others, some have partly same rules and some have no common rules with each other at all. The groups get bigger and more complex as new ways of symmetry are allowed, such as adding one more dimension to allow symmetries through that dimension as well and that always increases the possible symmetries because there's more axis to play around with. And then they do this mind-boggling difficult maths, and play with rules and add dimensions and at some point, they noticed that even though they add one more dimension after 195,403 (presumably 195,404) and try to flip along this new axis...They can't create anymore ways to make the objects symmetric. Flipping the object, doesn't work. It isn't symmetric anymore. Even though they just added an axis and should by all accounts be able to flip it, but can't.

1) It's pronounced Mic-eye, not Mic-ay.
2) For classifying symmetry groups into infinite families plus weirdos, you can't go wrong thinking first about rotations of 3-d objects. There's the infinite family D_n of rotations/reflections of n-gons, the infinite family C_n of just rotations of say n-gonal pyramids, and the three weirdos rotating the tetrahedron, the cube/octahedron, and the dodecahedron/icosahedron.

Abel's theorem is my favorite theorem.

It should also be noted that abstract algebra tends to share these type of general abstractions of things of concrete nature.

Groups are things like permutations. [Cayley's theorem!]
Rings are things like integers. [terminology like integral domain, principal ideal domain, prime ideal, unique factorization domain, euclidean domain supports this idea...].
Fields are things like numbers. [rational, real, and complex numbers-prime fields are a not so obvious one]
Modules are like when one takes a group [that is commutative] and considers how 'integer-like' things can add them up [since 'integer-like' means ring, we mean how rings act on the group] [Z-module is a prototypical exam, matrices over a ring [integer-like objects] is another one].
Vector fields is somewhat similar to a module except with 'number-like' things, that is fields-it is based on proportion more so then multiplicity as in the modules case.
Lattices are things based on the concept of 'inclusion'-set inclusion, group inclusion by 'normal subgroup', 'ring' [ideals generally aren't rings but...] inclusion by ideals, and so forth.

You can keep it abstract, but the examples just weren't enough to understand what a group is. actually, I think a look into some more of those 18 infinite groups while keeping it abstract, might have really helped.
Finally, the monster in the end felt kinda tossed on, as if you had run out of time. "And now that you have some idea about some easy to visualize groups: the monster is some other other group that you won't understand. bye"
Why it felt so disconnected for me is that there wasn't much mention of dimensions throughout the video. For example, I don't know if the ways a square can be rotated differ in abstraction from the ways a cube or tessaract can be rotated. The naturally arising question for me was: "why 196883 dimensions? why is the the symmetry between 196883dimensional objects simple, but the symetry between 25824584dimensional groups is not?
So, to sum up, I would love a follow up video that goes deeper into the abstraction. Without an abstract understanding of groups and only some simple applications like rotating a cube, the topic is just too hard to grasp.

Cantors diagonal argument is predicated on a logically impossible matrix. As with the permutation of the connectivity of only 6 points, a matrix based on the permutations of a(n infinite) set will grow linearly to the right and by the factorial downward. Diagonalization fails miserably for finite sets, and it does the same for infinite ones.

To make sure I understand this correctly: the chart at 18:39 reflects that the set of finite simple groups is countable and that it consists of 18 countable infinite subsets (with possible overlap) as well as 26 countable finite subsets?

I ask because I would have assumed that the answer to the question "how many simple groups are there" would be just "it's infinite"... Which turns out to be true, it's just that there are some groups that can be extended indefinitely by a simple algorithm and some that by their nature can only exist in spaces of certain specific dimensions—one of which is the "monster group", so named because it's the biggest of the non-infinite families.

Really really interesting. In some ways it's a baffling thing to come to, but when I think about it I realize it's befuddling in a familiar way. It makes me think of prime numbers. Prime numbers emerge so simply from basic arithmetic, and yet they exhibit behaviour that can't be fully described with arithmetic alone. The sequence of primes is in a sense "arbitrary": there's no rigid pattern to them, only some fuzzy tendencies. But in another way, the sequence of primes is anything but arbitrary: there is no accident, it is exactly what it must be.

I think that, to someone who is building mathematics from the ground up, prime numbers would be the first sign that things can't be kept in control, that there is no way to prevent simple rules from leading to surprising results. It would be the first indication that there are things like the "monster group" waiting in the mists ahead.

There is a frustrated expectation as for what exact reason, these groups are the way they are.

Let's put some intuition there and take the example from Dynkin Diagrams.

Under some restrictive rules, like the crystallographic restriction theorem; some classification of finite groups was provided; and in turn provided an upper boundary on complexity.

These rules (for us, still exquisitely arbitrary) must fundamentally set a roof on how symmetries multiply together to yield non-commutativity.

Thereby related to and impositive on the monster group's multiplication table, which is hinted to be more contrived (more irregular pattern of matrix entries) even than "easy" instances of some larger, albeit more regular among those first 18 groups mentioned.

Such that a minimalist faithful representation is a matrix with dimension 196k+ (so was it said).

As for the arbitrariness of the restriction choice, recall that in case of Lie Algebras, it was related to a layering rule - obtained from eigenvectors - to reduce N^2 generator rotations, down to representation of non-commutativity on N conserved charges (linear dimensions).

For finite groups (in fact, more on discreteness than finite bounding), there's no such crystallography as there isn't a Lie Bracket (generalization of vector product, producing N^2 rotations from N independent eigenvectors).

That, despite/while commutators can always be defined from matrix representations. However, the astounding minimum dimension of 196k+ suggests something very different from Triality in Dynkin Diagrams.

Instead, we know and wish to represent groups by a primitive 2D table, written on a sheet of paper.

To me, this sounds as reasonable to be that arbitrary (yet agreed upon by mathematicians as beautiful) rule. Not 100% satisfying, I know.

PS: we are cockroaches on a mathematical kitchen floor. Even if the cook could explain his/her reasons, we wouldn't understand. It's beyond us.

It seems like a deeper understanding of the monster group, better answers to the "why it's there" question, would be connected to compressions of that 4 gigabyte matrix representation. The permutation group on 101 elements could be represented with permutation matrices and that would be bigger than the 101 integers - but neither is more correct for any particular reason.

To look at it another way you could represent each of the 8*10^53 elements of the monster by just assigning each one a 180 bit representation arbitrarily - but then you might have a lot of trouble figuring out how to multiple the elements.

So really I suppose deeper understanding would go hand in hand with compressed representations together with improved multiplication algorithms for those representations.

What about the Tits group? Isn't it missing from the classification of simple groups?
According to Wikipedia, the classification theorem states that:

Every finite simple group is isomorphic to one of the following groups:

- a member of one of three infinite classes of such, namely:
- the cyclic groups of prime order,
- the alternating groups of degree at least 5,
- the groups of Lie type
- one of 26 groups called the "sporadic groups"
- the Tits group (which is sometimes considered a 27th sporadic group).

I remember in college (over 40 years ago) in a computability theory class we had homework assignment "Prove that there are only 2 unique groups of order 4" a bunch of the best of us spent hours rereading those words over and over again just trying to understand what it was they were asking. We finally figured out that there were 4 groups of order 4. That one was pretty easy. But how do we get it down to two. We finally realized that by reordering the rows and columns of some of the groups they were actually equivalent to others and there were only two unique groups. I've never felt more satisfaction over understanding something that was so purely abstract mathematically. I've never had a use for it but it sure was a sense of accomplishment when my little band computer science majors finally cracked it. Being in computer science I've always been much more of an applied mathematician than a theoretical mathematician but I will never forget this one problem that blew me away

Introduction to Group Theory was the greatest math course I ever took, especially considering how my adviser cautioned me, "this won't count as an elective. I suggest taking it only if you're extremely invested in learning about groups" ("extremely invested" were his exact words). As such, I took it pass/fail so I wouldn't have to worry about my GPA.

I aced that class and learned so many things about our world. It explained why there's no quintic equation. It explained the greatest theorem of our time, the Finite Simple Groups. It explained how all math can be derived from group operations. He also touched for a few minutes the applications in quantum physics.

I have fond memories of that class.

Edit: Heck yeah, the classification of finite simple groups! I hoped you'd use that as a way to justify M.

I don't know if you already know about Professor Mark Ronan and his interest in the Monster, but, if I may, a perfect pair of followup videos for this would be about (1) the dimension-24 kissing number 196560 and the Leech Lattice, and then (2) the largest Heegner number 163 and the character table of the Monster group.

Regarding the former video suggestion, on Mark's website, he writes:
> The existence of the Monster was proposed by Bernd Fischer, immediately after he discovered the Baby Monster, and it was later constructed by Robert Griess as the symmetry group of an algebra structure in 196,884 dimensions. His work split the space into three subspaces, and his main task was to show there were symmetries intermingling these subspaces. The dimensions of the subspaces are:
> 98,304 + 300 + 98,280 = 196,884
> The first number 98,304 = 212 × 24 comes from the Golay code in 24 dimensions.
> The second number 300 = 24 + 23 + 22 + … + 3 + 2 + 1 is the dimension of the space of 24-by-24 symmetric matrices.
> The third number 96,280 = 196,560 ÷ 2 comes from the Leech Lattice in 24 dimensions, where there are 196,560 vertices closest to a given vertex, forming 98,280 diametrically opposite pairs.

As for the latter video suggestion, I thought 3Blue1Brown style visualizations would be perfect for it. Since division on the complex plane looks like rotating+shrinking, factoring a (Gaussian) integer into its prime components means finding a set of path from the integer's gridpoint (a+bi) to the identity gridpoint (1+0i) where each path consists of integer-jumps to another gridpoint (i.e. division by a prime factor), and unique factorization means that the paths all contain the same set of integer-jumps, merely in different orders. That is to say, each gridpoint has a single set of numbers corresponding to its jump options (prime factors). However, for some reason, unique factorization is no longer guaranteed when the complex plane is vertically stretched, unless the amount of stretching is the square root of one of the 9 Heegner numbers (1, 2, 3, 7, 11, 19, 43, 67, 163). In other words, when the stretching is by any amount other than those 9, there will be gridpoints with multiple sets of numbers corresponding to jump options (prime factors). Now, the fact that there is only a finite number of options for preserving unique factorization is already pretty interesting, but that the largest amount of stretching is the square root of the dimension of space spanned by the functions generated by character table of the largest sporadic group makes it even more so. I wonder if the fact that 1+2*3^4=163 has anything to do with it, too.

Anywho, thanks again for your time and effort! And I'm still praying for a video on exotic spheres and one on the stable homotopy groups of spheres! ^_^

Another great introduction to an interesting field in mathematics (tips hat). If only I had an introduction like this when taking Abstract Algebra. The professor started with those abstract definitions and taught as if once he wrote something on the board it was crystal clear and we could move on. I remember thinking many times "I have so many questions but I don't understand enough of the material to know what questions I should be asking". By the end of the semester the class of roughly 20, with the exception of maybe 3 people bombed on the final (I being among that 17) and so he needed to curve so heavily that I somehow got an A. The key lesson I took away was that the formalism approach to teaching mathematics is great if you and your students are very comfortable with thinking in a formal way about mathematics, but it completely fails if you have students who need something more concrete. I'd say you have a very good mix of formalism and concrete application/example 👍

I'm not going to make any video about this, but if I had to, I would choose 12345678987654321 because this number is equal to 111111111². As you can see, this is a perfect square where the amount of 1s in the root correspond to the amount of digits (considered once) in the first number. Thinking that such a strange number would be a perfect square was pretty interesting, but something more interesting is when I tried numbers like 1, 121, 12321, 1234321 etc... where we had every time this condition of palindrome number where the central digit was repeated only once and found out they all follow the same rule as the first number I talked about.
1 = 1²
121 = 11²
12321 = 111²
1234321 = 1111²
...
12345678987654321 = 111111111²

Pretty astounding to me :)

Why are groups read right to left? All other math is read (by default) left to right) (of course in general many things are commutative). For example something that is not commutative and read left to right is the cross product. Vector addition is also generally thought as A+B drawn as first A, then B. Indeed if we think about orations, we know that the order for a 3D object matters. Reading left to right vs right to left will give you a different result for a pair of 3-space rotations.
